awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative Research: Improving the Reliability of Cable Broadband Networks with Proactive Network Maintenance
awd_abstract_narration:
High-speed Internet access plays an important role in modern life. It helps narrow the digital divide, enables e-commerce, and provides opportunities for remote work, study, and entertainment. In the US, cable Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are one of the few available infrastructures that can provide high-speed Internet access to US homes, and in many rural areas, they are often the only broadband choice. However, much measurement study has shown that broadband access networks have poor reliability. (Many parts of the cable networks are now decades old.)   This work aims to address this problem.  If successful, it can significantly improve the reliability of cable broadband networks, thereby improving Internet availability and quality of experience of millions of cable broadband users.

It is challenging to improve the reliability of cable networks because the "last-mile" links that connect a subscriber's home to the Internet are often made of coaxial cables. They are vulnerable to radio frequency interference and suffer from aging-related issues. These problems can manifest themselves as unrecoverable noisy signals, disrupting a subscriber's Internet connectivity.   The cable industry currently collects performance data from users' cable modems. However, there is a lack of systematic study on how to use this data to detect and localize network problems and to rank the severity of problems. Existing techniques often lead to an unacceptably high number of false positives in practice.   This work will develop algorithms and tools that can help detect and localize faults in cable networks and estimate the performance impact of network faults.  Specifically, the work will include 1) algorithms that use collected data to accurately detect faults inside a cable network; 2) algorithms that localize a fault to a geographical location by clustering anomalous data patterns; and 3) algorithms that estimate how many calls an ISP may receive given a network problem as a mechanism to prioritize repairs. In this project, these algorithms will be implemented in software. All algorithms and code resulting from this work will be made publicly available. The researchers anticipate that the algorithms developed in this project are also applicable to WiFi and cellular networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broadband access networks play an important role in modern life. They help narrow the digital divide, enable e-commerce, and provide opportunities for remote work, study, and entertainment. Their importance was further manifested by the COVID-19 pandemic, which highlighted the necessity of reliable and high-speed Internet access as more people relied on their broadband Internet connections for remote work, education, and staying connected with their loved ones.

However, many measurement studies have shown that broadband access networks have poor reliability. Yet it is challenging to improve the reliability of cable networks, partly due to the nature of the infrastructure. The link layer of cable networks has a rich Hybrid Fiber Coaxial (HFC) structure and cannot be treated simply as a physical layer abstraction. The 'last-mile' link that connects a user's home to the Internet is often made of coaxial cables, which are not resistant to radio frequency (RF) interference.

A main goal of this NSF-funded project is to develop machine learning techniques for diagnosing network failures in cable broadband networks. Accurate failure diagnosis can shorten failure repair time and save unnecessary repair efforts caused by faulty diagnoses. To this end, we obtained three major outcomes from this project:

1) We developed a machine learning (ML) system called CableMon that can reliably detect failures in cable broadband networks using data collected from the DOCSIS's built-in proactive network maintenance (PNM) system. We collaborated with an anonymous mid-size cable Internet Service Provider (ISP) and obtained eight months of PNM data and the corresponding customer trouble tickets. Using these data, we were able to train an ML classifier that extracts reliable features from PNM data for failure detection. The features we extracted improved the failure detection accuracy by eight times compared to the tool the ISP was using back then. The work was published at a premium networking conference (NSDI'20), and the ISP we collaborated with adopted some of the features we extracted for failure detection in their networks. The improved failure detection method has significantly reduced their operational costs.

2) Using the PNM data, we conducted a rigorous measurement study to characterize physical-layer transmission errors in cable broadband networks. Packet loss rate in a broadband network is an important quality of service metric. Previous work that characterizes broadband performance does not separate packet loss caused by physical layer transmission errors from that caused by congestion. We were able to investigate the physical layer transmission errors using data provided by our collaborating ISP. The data were collected from 77K+ devices that spread across 394 hybrid-fiber-coaxial (HFC) network segments during a 16-month period. We made a number of discoveries that were relevant to network operations and network research. We estimated that physical-layer errors could contribute to 12% to 25% of packet loss in the cable ISPs measured by the FCC’s Measuring Broadband America project. The average error loss rates of different HFC network segments vary by more than six orders of magnitude, from on the order of ten to minus six percent to on the order of one percent. Users in persistently high-error-rate networks do not report more trouble tickets than other users. This work was published at NSDI'22.

3) Finally, continuing our work on CableMon, we developed a clustering-based ML system called TelApart that can separate faults located in an individual subscriber's premises from those located inside the cable broadband networks. We use metrics derived from an ISP's customer trouble tickets to programmatically tune the model's hyperparameters so that an ISP can deploy TelApart in various conditions without hand-tuning its hyperparameters. We also addressed the data challenges, as the telemetry data collected by the PNM system contain numerous missing, duplicated, and unaligned data points. We evaluated TelApart's diagnosis accuracy using manually labeled data. We found that TelApart is able to achieve a Rand Index of 0.91 (1.0 being the highest). This work is currently under submission.
